huntYears.SEASON_DATE_TEXT: Archery: Aug 23-Sept 19, 2023 / Any Legal Weapon: Oct 7-Oct 19, 2023 / Muzzleloader: Nov 1 - Nov 9, 2023

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This elk herd has seen a reduction in cow numbers the past several years.  Average age of bulls has decreased and is currently below objective.  This is a tough hunt; elk move back and forth across state lines.  330+ size bulls are rare.  Elk hunters should expect to see deer hunters.  This unit also sees a lot of tourism due to the Green River and Flaming Gorge Reservoir.  There is a Landowner Association in this unit and the majority of the private property is towards Colorado and Wyoming state lines. There was a fire this summer on the north and east sides of Goslin Mountain.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
Due to recent storms, several roads in the 3 Corners vicinity have washed out and are impassable to any vehicle, including side by sides and ATVs. Please do not harm the habitat by trying to drive off road around wash outs. Driving off road is illegal.

Cellular phone coverage is spotty on this hunt unit. Satellite phones do work in the area. A "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety can be used if you decide to camp in an area without cell phone service and do not wish to drive to reach service. Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.

Camps should be kept clean to prevent bear incidents. Food should be kept inside vehicles or bear-proof containers. Coolers are not bear-proof. Bears have gotten into camps in the past. Number and severity of bear incidents differ by year depending on weather and other food availability. Meat and garbage should be put away inside a vehicle or hung in a tree above 8 feet off the ground and 3 feet away from the trunk or any branches of the tree.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically between the hunting seasons.  Be prepared for rain, snow, wind and heat.  Be very cautious of lightning while hunting on high ridges or exposed slopes.  Early fall snow storms occur occasionally in this area.  Most years the snow will melt off within a day or two until through the first week of October.  Some years a big snowstorm will hit the beginning of October and make some roads impassable or very muddy.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 100~700~600~~~5.5–6.0~5.4~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Migration Patterns:
Elk in this unit move back and forth across state lines quite regularly. Cow elk are sensitive to hunting pressure. Success rates on this unit vary widely by year depending on where the elk are.

Scouting Tips:
In warm weather, hunters do best hunting water sources in mornings and evenings. Later in the season when there’s usually more water available, hunters do best glassing for elk and then working to get close for a shot. Visibility on this unit is high due to the lack of trees. Elk are most active in the early mornings and late afternoons, which are the best times for scouting elk prior to and during the hunts.

Behavior:
Like other wildlife, elk are most active in the early mornings and evenings, but they can be up and moving any time of day. If it’s a dry year, they will be more concentrated around water sources, and these can sometimes be hunted successfully. On average precipitation or wet years, elk won’t be as concentrated around water. Elk can move long distances in short periods of time, especially if they are disturbed by vehicles or people. Elk can be called in close for a shot during the rut.

Elk rut:
The elk rut usually runs from mid-September to early October.

Where to find elk:
Elk are found throughout much of the unit. There are water sources across the unit in the form of stock ponds, guzzlers, creeks, and springs. In warm and dry weather, elk can be found close to these water sources.

Recommended areas in the North Slope, Three Corners:
Good areas to look for elk include Bare Top, Goslin Mountain, Home Mountain, Bender Mountain, and Dutch John Mountain.

huntMaster.SPECIAL_INSTRUCTIONS: Hunters may hunt all limited entry seasons for this unit using the appropriate weapon for the open season
huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: REQUIRED: click here or call 1-800-221-0659 to report your harvest. You must report your harvest, even if you did not take an animal, within 30 days of the season end date that is printed on your permit; failure to do so may result in you not being able to apply for big game species in subsequent years. Submitting teeth or other biological samples from your animal, or having your animal checked by a DWR representative or CWMU operator does NOT fulfill your mandatory harvest reporting requirement.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: 90% Public Land - US Forest Service lands, BLM, and State
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
All Campgrounds on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service and BLM. Camping outside of official campgrounds is also permitted on most of the public lands. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the US Forest Service. Maps and camping regulations are available on their websites.
Ashley National Forest: http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/ashley/home
huntBoundaryInfos.COUNTY_ROAD_INFO: County Road Access information: http://www.daggettcounty.org/index.aspx?nid=17 and http://www.utahcommuterlink.com/
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
Most roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the US Forest Service or BLM and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the US Forest Service. There is no vehicle access allowed on Baretop.
Ashley National Forest: http://www.fs.usda.gov/detail/ashley/home/?cid=STELPRDB5432815
BLM: http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/vernal.html
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: The boundary of this hunt unit does not include Tribal Trust Lands and does not have much private land included.  Hunters should receive written permission from private landowners prior to the start of the hunts if they wish to hunt private property.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Daggett County--Boundary begins at the Flaming Gorge Reservoir main channel western shoreline on the east side of Lucerne Point at the Utah-Wyoming state line; east on this state line to the Utah-Colorado state line; south on this state line to the Green River; west along this river to the Flaming Gorge Reservoir west shoreline; west along this shoreline to the Utah-Wyoming state line; east along the state line to Lucerne Point; east around Lucerne Point to the Utah-Wyoming State line. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Dutch John. Boundary questions? Call Vernal office, 435-781-9453.
